transcription.text: The following talk invites us to follow the journey of Autogen.
From a leading open source framework for multi-agent applications to a complete redesign
that lays the foundation for the future of a GENTIC AI research and applications.
With the release of Autogen0.4, the framework's new layered architecture provides flexibility
and scalability and includes an ecosystem of extensions and applications,
some created by the same team, such as Magentic1, a team of generalist agents, and Studio,
a low-code developer tool. Autogen0.4 is also a story about collaboration between
MSR, partners with a Microsoft, and a vibrant open source community.
Hi, I am Guggen Vansol and I am a researcher at Microsoft Research AI Frontiers.
And today I'll talk about some exciting technical updates to Autogen,
a leading open source framework for a GENTIC AI.
And although I am presenting, this is joint work with many incredible colleagues and interns
and Microsoft over the last year.
Autogen is a leading open source framework for multi-agent applications
that we release in fall 2023. It enables developers and researchers to create intelligent
applications using large language models, tool use, and multi-agent collaboration balance.
With Autogen0, our goal has been to lead the innovation in a GENTIC AI research.
When we first launched Autogen in fall 2023, it quickly became the leading open source framework for
GENTIC AI. And it continues to empower developers and researchers in many, many domains,
including business process automation, marketing, finance, security, and others.
Since Autogen's launch, we have not just been maintaining it, we have been listening
closely to feedback from developers and researchers. And in this rapidly evolving landscape of AI
their expectations were high. Use us told us that they needed greater modularity and the ability
to reuse agency, they also asked for better support for debugging and scaling their GENTIC solutions.
And finally, there were many asked to enhance the core quality and maturity of the platform.
Percewing these needs required us to question our assumptions and even possibly reimagine the platform.
So in early 2024, we use these learnings to experiment with alternate architectures.
And we ended up adopting an actor model for multi-agent orchestration.
The actor model is a well-known programming model for concurrent programming and high-use systems.
Here actors are the computational building blocks that can exchange messages and also perform work.
In fall 2024, we announced a preview of this version. And this new year,
we're thrilled to announce a full release. In summary, Audigen.4 is a response to
address a user's feedback in this evolving landscape of AI research.
Audigen is now not just a framework, but it's a whole ecosystem for a GENTIC AI.
It provides you with a framework that lets you build sophisticated agents and multi-agent applications,
and it also provides you with developer tools and many well-defined applications.
Let me first tell you about the Audigen framework.
At the heart of this release is a layered architecture that is designed for flexibility and scalability.
At the base is Audigen Core. This layer implements the actor model for agents.
Building on Core is Audigen Agent Shad. This layer provides a simple and easy to use API that is
perfect for rapid prototyping. And building on Core and Agent Shad is extensions.
This layer provides advanced clients, agents, and teams, and integrations with third-party software.
This layer architecture is nice because whether you're an advanced developer or a researcher
prototyping new ideas, Audigen provides you with the tools you need for your project stage of development.
The Core implements an actor model for GENTIC AI. At the highest level, this implementation
provides two key features. The first is A synchronous message exchange between agents. It does
so by providing a runtime. And then it also provides event-reven agents that perform computation in
response to these messages. There are several implications of this design. And one of them is
that it decouples how the messages are delivered between the agents from how the agents handle them.
This naturally improves the modularity and scalability of a GENTIC workflows built with Audigen,
especially for deployment. The Core's event-reven architecture provides several other benefit.
For example, it provides affordances to observe and control agent behavior, which is crucial for
a responsible development of a GENTIC technology. It also enables running multiple agents
on different processes and even implementing them using different languages. Finally, it enables developers
to implement a large class of multi-edian patterns, including static and dynamic workforce.
When we release Audigen, one of the first things that developers absolutely loved about it
was its simplicity and the many pre-built agents and teams that had provided, such as the user
proxy agent and the system agent and the group chat between multiple agents. With the Audigen
agent chat layer, we're maintaining these features and adding tons of more essential features,
such as streaming support, serialization, state management and memory for agents, and finally
full types of support for a better development experience. Please check out the link below for
the migration guide. Finally, the extension layer provides advanced run times, tools, clients,
and ecosystem integrations that continuously expand the framework capabilities. In addition to the
framework, this new release also provides upgrades to essential developer tools and applications
built using Audigen. And here, I'll briefly mention two of them. In late 2023, we also released
Audigen Studio, which is a low core tool for authoring multi-edian applications. And we are
excited to announce that with the version 0.4, Studio has received massive upgrades.
It now supports a Dragon Drop multi-edian builder. It supports real-time updates as agent sawstass,
flow visualizations and execution controls so that the users remain in control and component
gallery so that the community can discover and build on each other's work. We've always believed
that the framework should enable state-of-the-art applications for solving complex task with agent,
which is why we've been building applications with the framework ourselves and using that to guide
the framework's development. Last year, we released Magentic One, a state-of-the-art multi-edian
team for solving file and web-related tasks built using Audigen. And now it's developer API
and general capabilities, such as the sophisticated orchestrators and specialized agents,
such as the web server and the file server, are now available in the Audigen ecosystem.
For us, this new ecosystem is only the beginning and sets the stage for future innovation in
agentic AR. Over the past two years, our team had made early progress in AI agents and we continue
to deeply think about the changing landscape of current AI research and continue to invest
in taking steps to help lead the innovation on agents. And by the way, we're also working closely
with our colleagues as semantic kernel to provide an enterprise-ready multi-edian runtime for Audigen.
Thank you for attending Microsoft Research Forum. Please check out these links to learn more about Audigen.
